answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
I don't have an RFP, but I do have a few quotes for services rendered if you're interested. I can say in my experience producing video that the costs can vary widely by geographic area, by experience level of the crew, and by things that impact the final product like how many cameras you need, if you need studio space, the length of the final piece, sound, editing, and more. 
If this is a recurring and fairly straightforward thing like recording and broadcasting council meetings, you can check out national service providers. You could give your videographer the option to beat the price if it looks competitive. If you're coming to the annual conference, there are usually a few such providers in the exhibit hall.
Once you have a little more info, you could also change to a fixed price contract versus hourly - we'll pay you $X to do this, and you can spend as much time as you'd like rewiring things.

Does anyone have a really detailed RFP for Videographers?  
My township pays way too much to a videographer who uses technical jargon to explain why he has to work countless hours rewiring things and such, and it's fishy to me.
